measured_by: horizontal slider scale from 'I hate it!' to 'I love it!'
justification: "Participants responded to the question, 'How much do you like this item?' using a horizontal slider scale to indicate their value rating for the item (from 'I hate it!' to 'I love it!', with 'I donâ€™t care.' at the center of the scale)."

measured_by: width of solid bar expanded around slider cursor
justification: "Participants then responded to the question, 'What degree of certainty do you have?' by expanding a solid bar symmetrically around the cursor of the slider scale to indicate their uncertainty about the value rating they had just provided."

measured_by: horizontal slider scale from 'Not at all' to 'Absolutely'
justification: "Participants then responded to the question, 'Are you sure about your choice?' using a horizontal slider scale (from 'Not at all' to 'Absolutely'). This provided a subjective measure of choice confidence."

measured_by: horizontal slider scale from 'Not at all' to 'Really a lot'
justification: "Finally, participants responded to the question, 'To what extent did you think about this choice?' using a horizontal slider scale (from 'Not at all' to 'Really a lot'). This provided a subjective measure of mental effort expenditure."

measured_by: response time (RT) recorded for each choice
justification: The slider-based effort rating was "supplement[ed] [by] the objective effort proxy of response time," indicating RT was used as an objective measure of mental effort.

measured_by: congruence between actual choice and pre-choice value ratings
justification: "Consistency refers to choices that are congruent with preferences inferred from pre-choice value ratings."

measured_by: spreading of alternatives (SoA: post-minus-pre value difference)
justification: "We examined the spreading of alternatives (SoA), which is the post-minus prechoice value difference between the chosen and unchosen options. This measure supports the idea that values are refined during deliberation."
